description: From Late Latin quantum, noun use of neuter form of Latin quantus (“how much”).

entries.meaning: Of a change, sudden or discrete, without intermediate stages.

definitionGroups.group: (physics) Involving quanta, quantum mechanics or other aspects of quantum physics.

entries.meaning: (computing theory) Relating to a quantum computer.

nouns.description: quantum (countable and uncountable, plural quantums or quanta)

definitionGroups.group: (now chiefly South Asia or law) The total amount of something; quantity. [from 17th c.]

entries.meaning: (law) The amount of compensation awarded to a successful party in a lawsuit.
(law) The length or magnitude of the sentence handed down to someone who has been found guilty of a crime.
The amount or quantity observably present, or available. [from 18th c.]
examples: Each man has only a quantum of compassion, he argued, and mine is used up for the day.

entries.meaning: (physics) The smallest possible, and therefore indivisible, unit of a given quantity or quantifiable phenomenon. [from 20th c.]
examples: The quantum of light energy was later called a photon.

entries.meaning: (computing) The amount of time allocated for a thread to perform its work in a multithreaded environment.

examples: Developing for quantum has never been more accessible.

entries.meaning: (medicine) The minimum dose of a pathogen required to cause an infection.
(mathematics) A definite portion of a manifoldness, limited by a mark or by a boundary.
